content: Yes, another great example of a movie where sound editing enhances the tension in the climax is the 1973 horror classic "The Exorcist." In the climax of the movie, the main character Father Karras confronts the demon possessing a young girl named Regan. Throughout the scene, the sound design is used to create a sense of chaos and terror. There are eerie and distorted sounds playing in the background, such as the sound of a clock ticking and the sound of heavy breathing. There are also intense screams and guttural growls, which add to the sense of violence and terror. The use of silence is also very effective in adding to the tension, as it makes the sudden sounds of violence even more startling. The sound editing in this scene is crucial to making it one of the most terrifying scenes in horror movie history.
